trically. In the extratropics, the location of the landmasses serves

. The surface temperature response to GHGs and
aerosols (Fig. 3c, d) is constrained to the land in these prescribed
SST runs. However, the land surface temperature response to the

tially weaker spatial correlation of surface energy
during the Northern Hemisphere winter-time (DJF) may be
attributable to the higher variability and greater in
transient eddies on stationary Rossby wave patterns during the
In the tropics, changes in deep tropical (20°S
tion due to GHGs and aerosols can also act as a source for
extratropical Rossby waves. The fact that the simulated deep
tropical precipitation changes are indeed antisymmetric (
0.54) (Fig. 3e, f) may contribute to the similar extratropical
wave patterns. Interestingly, it is not straightforward why the two
forcers would give rise to antisymmetric, rather than symmetric,
precipitation changes. In fact, a thermodynamic scaling argument
and aerosols increase tropospheric absorption of radiative energy,
via increased absorption of longwave radiation in the case of
GHGs and of shortwave radiation in the case of aerosols, and thus
have suppressing effects on tropical mean precipitation
Indeed, in our simulations, both forcers decrease tropical mean
In our view, the antisymmetric spatial pattern of these
precipitation reductions is driven mainly by the opposite
SST contrast patterns (Fig. 3c, d) and associated monsoonal
circulation changes, which are dynamical in nature. The aerosol
cools the land surface relative to the ocean, decreasing rainfall
preferentially over the land surface, while the GHGs warm the
land surface relative to the ocean, increasing the rainfall
preferentially over the land surface. Analysis as part of the
Precipitation Driver and Response Model Intercomparison
nds similar behavior and mechanisms in the fast
future impacts of GHG and aerosol forcing in the CMIP5
ner-scale features of the fast response to GHGs
and aerosols that are evident in our simulations have also been
rmed in other analyses, such as weakening of the South
Asian monsoon in the fast response to historical aerosol
The underlying driver of atmospheric energy redistribution
Our above analysis of the mechanisms of surface pattern corre-
lation demonstrates that the atmospheric circulation is an ef
cient homogenizer of heterogeneous forcings, even under
SST conditions. Indeed, a simple energy balance analysis, based
on energetic constraints alone, illuminates why this atmospheric
homogenization must occur (Fig. 4). Because land surface and
atmospheric energy perturbations rapidly equilibrate to zero, the
denoting the radiative and heat components,
respectively) must equal the TOA ERF over oceans (ERF
. Vertical longwave and shortwave radiative energy
conservation dictates that the TOA ERF must equal the sum of
absorption less emission) atmospheric absorption change (ERF
ocean will be equal to the total atmospheric absorption change
over land and ocean plus the land surface radiative perturbation
), a balance that is evident in our
simulations (Table 1). This coupling between the atmospheric
and surface energetics over the land and the ocean dictates that
most of the spatial heterogeneity in the initial TOA forcing
cannot be maintained in the response and must be rapidly
transformed (from radiation to heat) and redistributed (from the
land surface and atmosphere to the ocean surface) by the atmo-
spheric circulation. This circulation adjustment process is fun-
damentally responsible for the similar ocean heat
perturbation patterns between GHGs and aerosols.
Notably, the fast homogenization described in this work
operates primarily within a single hemisphere. The ratio of
Northern Hemisphere to Southern Hemisphere TOA ERF does
cantly from that of the surface energy
perturbation (1.0 and 1.1, respectively, for GHGs and 3.2 and
Hadley circulation, the main mode of atmospheric cross-
equatorial transport, cannot readily respond to perturbations
constraining homogenization to within a given hemisphere.
Our work reveals that, even on the short timescales captured in
xed-SST simulations, GHGs and aerosols can be expected to
produce strongly correlated spatial patterns of change across a
range of variables. This is enforced by the symmetric perturbation
to the extratropical circulation provided by land
xed by the location of the land-
masses and, thus, relatively insensitive to the structure of the
initial forcing. Analysis of the spatial correlation of atmosphere-
and-land-only change in response to GHGs and aerosols in a
range of models will be crucial to improved understanding of this
